awd_titl_txt: RUI: The Timing and Evolution of Devonian Fire Systems and Their Implications for Atmospheric Oxygen Concentration
awd_abstract_narration:
Charcoal can be preserved in the rock record, and so it is an excellent indicator of wildfire activity in deep-time. The earliest known charcoal evidence of wildfires dates from about 420 million years ago when there were no trees and plants were extremely small and moss-like. These plants required very wet environments for growth and reproduction. The small size of plants and their dependence on moist conditions means that they should be a poor source of fuel for wildfires. However, there are a significant number of sites from this time 420-400 million years ago that preserve charcoal and thus evidence of ancient wildfires. There are very few charcoals preserved over the following 30 million years, which is surprising since vegetation around the world became larger and more independent of water and so a better source of fuel for fire. This proposal aims to investigate rocks from North America deposited during the time interval from 420-359 million years ago (the Devonian Period) when evidence of wildfires is lacking. This study will assess whether this anomaly in fire abundance really exists and what factors may have controlled it, including whether oxygen in the atmosphere may have been too low to have supported fires. Undergraduate interns will be engaged in the project and trained in fieldwork and laboratory techniques related to the study of fossil charcoal. At a time when the global impact of fires on many communities is growing, this project will provide these undergraduates an opportunity to share topical and exciting results on fires in deep time with both the scientific community and, through online content, the broader general public.
 
Preliminary evidence indicates that global fire occurrences during the Early to Mid-Devonian were not affected primarily by fuel but rather, flammability was governed by atmospheric oxygen concentration (pO2). This master variable of the Earth system is considered to have profoundly impacted metazoan evolution, but its quantification in deep time is uncertain. This proposal aims to test the hypothesis that pO2 was the primary driver of fire occurrence at this time by seeking and isolating charcoal from a range of North American Devonian-age sedimentary settings and assessing it in terms of sedimentary setting, taxonomy and petrographic characteristics. Comprehensively determining early fire regime evolution will afford new insights into the evolution of fire feedback into biogeochemical cycles and will permit models of pO2 during the Devonian to be critically examined. These data will collectively provide base level insights into environmental change during this key interval in the terrestrialization of Earth. Undergraduate interns will be engaged in the project and trained in fieldwork and laboratory techniques related to the study of fossil charcoal. These undergraduates will continue their projects during the academic year as capstones and disseminate their results through presentations at conferences and through collaboration in scientific publications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project: The Timing and evolution of Devonian Fire Systems

Contact PI:  Ian Glasspool

Organization: Colby College

Wildfire is an increasingly pervasive occurrence in today’s world. For a fire to ignite and spread, three prerequisites must exist. First there must be potentially combustible, usually dry, plant biomass. Second, there must be a source of ignition. Prior to man’s activities, this was predominantly lightning. Thirdly there must be sufficient oxygen in the atmosphere for fire to propagate. Levels of atmospheric oxygen have fluctuated over deep time, but in the present-day approximate to 21%. Experiments have shown that there must be at least 16% oxygen in the atmosphere before a wildfire in dried biomass will propagate. When biomass is burned, charcoal results, and this is used as a direct fossil proxy for wildfire. Prior to the results of the current project, the earliest known occurrence of charcoal was dated at ~420 million years ago.

Results of the current project demonstrate that Earth experienced wildfires at least as early as 430 million years ago in the Silurian Period, and possibly earlier (~445 million years ago). These first fires burned a vegetation largely dominated by enigmatic plant/fungal fossils known as nematophytes. These organisms varied greatly in size, though one, Prototaxites an occasionally giant phallic fossil reaching up to 8 m in height and 1 m in girth, was a common constituent of these fires preserved as charcoal.

Silurian charcoal is rare in the fossil record, though this evidence may be limited by both the small size of most land plants and sparser sampling of deposits of this age. As charcoal is present as far back as at least the Middle Silurian the minimum fire threshold for atmospheric oxygen (16%) must have been met during that time. This increase in atmospheric oxygen was essential to the transition of animal life on to land. However, it is not until terrestrial plants had diversified and animals had become better established on land during the Devonian Period (~420-360 million years ago) that there is more extensive evidence of charcoal reported.

Prior to our findings, scientists used an absence of charcoal during the Middle Devonian (~395-380 million years ago) to hypothesize that this ‘charcoal gap’ represented a period of low atmospheric oxygen. Our results demonstrate that this apparent absence is, in fact, a sampling artefact. Fires did burn during this interval, as evidenced by both visible charcoal in the rocks of Maine and Wyoming, and the identification of microscopic charcoal at multiple other localities of this age. These findings indicate that, contrary to many prevailing oxygenation models, levels of atmospheric oxygen exceeded 16% in the Middle Devonian as the first trees and forest began to appear on land.

While researching these early fires, a serendipitous fossil find was made in New Brunswick, Canada, and the PIs were asked to contribute their expertise. Funds from the grant were used to help investigate and describe an extreme new tree (Sanfordiacaulis) with a growth form unlike any tree previously reported. These findings were reported widely in national (e.g., NYTimes, CNN, Forbes, The Wall Street Journal, Newsweek, Live Science) and international (Canadian Broadcast Corporation, The Independent [UK], BBC (UK), Scientia.nl [Netherlands], L’Obs [France])) media, and the PIs appeared as podcast guests with In Defense of Plants, amongst other online programs. According to the New Brunswick Museum, one month after the story appeared in these, and other, media outlets, 36-40 million viewers had read about the plant. A Google search of “Sanfordiacaulis” or “Dr. Seuss Tree” results in >150,000 unique URLs.

 

Data from the project have been included in one museum exhibit at the National Museum of Nature and Science, Tokyo, where over 50,000 visitors paid to see “The Natural History of Wildfire” and exhibit now transferred online: https://www.kahaku.go.jp/english/event/2022/11wildfire/. The fossil Sanfordiacaulis will be displayed at the New Brunswick Museum, Saint John, Canada, and will become the focal point of a new permanent exhibit in the town of Norton where it was discovered. Scientific presentations on the project were made in Prague, Czech Republic, and Chicago, Phoenix, and Reston in the United States. Six scientific papers directly related to the project were published and are freely available. These include three manuscripts in the journal GEOLOGY (https://doi.org/10.1130/G50193.1, https://doi.org/10.1130/G52348.1, https://doi.org/10.1130/G52648.1), one in Current Biology (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2024.01.011), one in the Geological Society of London (https://doi-org.colby.idm.oclc.org/10.1144/jgs2022-072), and one in PALAIOS (http://dx.doi.org/10.2110/palo.2024.009).
